Other sites of involvement include the liver, lung, lymph nodes, and retroperitoneum.  The vast majority of cases follow a benign clinical course.  However, cases of metastatic angiomyolipomas with sarcomatoid features have been described.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic variant of fibroma characterized by the presence of numerous dilated vascular channels.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic variant of fibroma characterized by the presence of numerous dilated vascular channels.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A vascular proliferation characterized by the presence of prominent endothelial cells and the formation of vascular channels. Hemangioendotheliomas may display borderline or low grade characteristics.

Concepts.definition: A vascular proliferation characterized by the presence of prominent endothelial cells and the formation of vascular channels. Hemangioendotheliomas may display borderline or low grade characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The most common odontogenic tumor, arising from the epithelial component of the embryonic tooth and usually affecting the molar-ramus region of the mandible or maxilla.  Although most ameloblastomas are morphologically and clinically benign, they may cause extensive local destruction, recur, or metastasize.

Concepts.definition: The most common odontogenic tumor, arising from the epithelial component of the embryonic tooth and usually affecting the molar-ramus region of the mandible or maxilla.  Although most ameloblastomas are morphologically and clinically benign, they may cause extensive local destruction, recur, or metastasize.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An immune response that occurs following exposure to an innocuous antigen, but that does not require the presence of preformed antibodies to the antigen.

Concepts.definition: An immune response that occurs following exposure to an innocuous antigen, but that does not require the presence of preformed antibodies to the antigen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Atrophy of the cerebral cortex and/or cerebellum due to chronic ethanol consumption.

Concepts.definition: Atrophy of the cerebral cortex and/or cerebellum due to chronic ethanol consumption.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The property of remaining in close proximity, as that resulting from the physical attraction of molecules to a substance or the molecular attraction existing between the surfaces of contacting bodies.

Concepts.definition: The property of remaining in close proximity, as that resulting from the physical attraction of molecules to a substance or the molecular attraction existing between the surfaces of contacting bodies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mixed adenocarcinoma and squamous cell or epidermoid carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An invasive carcinoma composed of malignant glandular cells and malignant squamous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The growth of endometrial tissue inside the muscular wall of the uterus. Clinical manifestations include pain, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia.

Concepts.definition: The growth of endometrial tissue inside the muscular wall of the uterine corpus. Clinical manifestations include pain, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A usually benign neoplasm arising from the breast. It is characterized by the proliferation of cells with myoepithelial differentiation around spaces which are lined by epithelial cells. Rarely, the epithelial and/or myoepithelial cells may undergo malignant transformation. Cases with malignant transformation may follow an aggressive clinical course, including recurrences and local and distant metastases.

Concepts.definition: A usually benign tumor arising from the breast. It is characterized by the proliferation of cells with myoepithelial differentiation around spaces which are lined by epithelial cells. Rarely, the epithelial and/or myoepithelial cells may undergo malignant transformation. Cases with malignant transformation may follow an aggressive clinical course, including recurrences and local and distant metastases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: shaped like a tube; of or pertaining to a tubule. (On-line Medical Dictionary): A neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Shaped like a tube; of or pertaining to a tubule.

A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or resembling papilla.: A neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or resembling papilla.

A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract. -- 2004: A rare benign epithelial tumor composed of irregular, proliferating nests and islands of epithelium, including solid and gland-like sebaceous elements, surrounded by lymphoid stroma. Most occur in the parotid gland. Symptoms include a progressively enlarging, painless mass.  Sebaceous lymphadenocarcinoma is the malignant counterpart. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

A rare, benign epithelial neoplasm composed of irregular proliferating nests and islands of epithelium, including solid and gland-like sebaceous elements, surrounded by lymphoid stroma. Most occur in the parotid gland. Symptoms include a progressively enlarging, painless mass.  Sebaceous lymphadenocarcinoma is the malignant counterpart.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mixed Tumor of the Skin (Chondroid Syringoma)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mixed Tumor of the Skin (Chondroid Syringoma)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare, benign, slow-growing and painless neoplasm of sweat glands. It usually arises in the head and neck. It is characterized by the presence of a mesenchymal chondroid stroma, fibrosis, and epithelial structures.

Concepts.definition: A rare, benign, slow-growing and painless neoplasm of sweat glands. It usually arises in the head and neck. It is characterized by the presence of a mesenchymal chondroid stroma, fibrosis, and epithelial structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Rare chronic inflammatory disease involving the small blood vessels. It is of unknown etiology and characterized by mucocutaneous ulceration in the mouth and genital region and uveitis with hypopyon. The neuro-ocular form may cause blindness and death. SYNOVITIS, THROMBOPHLEBITIS, gastrointestinal ulcerations, RETINAL VASCULITIS, and OPTIC ATROPHY may occur as well.

Concepts.definition: A rare chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology. It is characterized by the development of ulcers in the mouth and genital region and uveitis. Other signs and symptoms include arthritis, deep vein thrombosis and superficial thrombophlebitis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that has undergone autolysis, or self-digestion by the specimen's own digestive enzymes.

Concepts.definition: A specimen that has undergone autolysis, or self-digestion by the specimen's own digestive enzymes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: High Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: High Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with severe dysplasia and the formation of micropapillary, cribriform, or solid patterns. The nuclei show marked pleomorphism and have prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity is usually present. There is comedo-type of necrosis present in the ducts. The necrotic debris is surrounded by pleomorphic malignant cells.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, High Grade
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with severe dysplasia and the formation of micropapillary, cribriform, or solid patterns. The nuclei show marked pleomorphism and have prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity is usually present. There is comedo-type of necrosis present in the ducts. The necrotic debris is surrounded by pleomorphic malignant cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or borderline cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The epithelial cells line the cystic spaces which contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenomas.

Concepts.definition: A benign or borderline cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The epithelial cells line the cystic spaces which contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cyst that is attached to the fallopian tube and originates from the remnants of the Mullerian duct.

Concepts.definition: A cystic structure located between the ovary and fallopian tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adenocarcinoma with morphologic characteristics similar to hepatocellular carcinoma, arising from an anatomic site other than the liver.

Concepts.definition: An adenocarcinoma with morphologic characteristics similar to hepatocellular carcinoma, arising from an anatomic site other than the liver.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mixed adenocarcinoma and squamous cell or epidermoid carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An invasive carcinoma composed of malignant glandular cells and malignant squamous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign neoplasm arising from mesothelial cells. It is characterized by the formation of glandular and tubular patterns. It can occur in several anatomic sites including the pleura, peritoneum, and epididymis.

Concepts.definition: A benign, well-circumscribed neoplasm arising from mesothelial cells. It is characterized by the formation of glandular and tubular patterns. It usually involves the paratesticular region, uterus, and fallopian tube. Rare cases involving the pleura, peritoneum, adrenal gland, and liver have also been reported.

PermissibleValues.value: Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) Or Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion (SIL) \ Mild (CIN I) Or Low Grade (LGSIL)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A precancerous neoplastic process that affects the cervical epithelium without evidence of invasion. It is usually associated with human papillomavirus infection. It is characterized by the presence of mild atypia in the superficial epithelial layer that may be associated with koilocytosis. Maturation is present in the upper two thirds of the epithelium. Mitotic figures are not numerous and are present in the basal third of the epithelium.

Concepts.definition: Squamous or glandular cervical intraepithelial neoplasia characterized by the presence of mild dysplastic changes.

PermissibleValues.value: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) \ Unknown Malignant Potential
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor of Uncertain Malignant Potential

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor of Uncertain Malignant Potential
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A gastrointestinal stromal tumor that is characterized by a maximum diameter greater than 5 cm and equal or less than 10 cm (gastric localization), or greater than 2 cm and equal or less than 5 cm (intestinal localization) and no more than 5 mitotic figures per 50 high power fields.

Concepts.longName: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor of Uncertain Malignant Potential
Concepts.definition: A gastrointestinal stromal tumor that is characterized by a maximum diameter greater than 5 cm and equal or less than 10 cm (gastric localization), or greater than 2 cm and equal or less than 5 cm (intestinal localization) and no more than 5 mitotic figures per 50 high power fields.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by inactivation of the tumor suppressor gene MEN-1. Patients may develop hyperparathyroidism and parathyroid gland adenomas, pituitary gland adenomas, pancreatic islet cell neoplasms, and carcinoid tumors.

Concepts.definition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by inactivation of the tumor suppressor gene MEN-1. Patients may develop hyperparathyroidism and parathyroid gland adenomas, pituitary gland adenomas, pancreatic islet cell neoplasms, and carcinoid tumors.

PermissibleValues.value: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) \ Idiopathic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (IPAH)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Increased blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs; the etiology is unknown.

Concepts.definition: Increased blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs; the etiology is unknown.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multisystem disease chiefly affecting males, characterized by necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving the upper and lower respiratory tracts, glomerulonephritis, and variable degrees of systemic, small vessel vasculitis, which is generally considered to represent an aberrant hypersensitivity reaction to an unknown antigen. (Dorland, 27th ed)

Concepts.definition: A rare, autoimmune, systemic medium and small size vasculitis. It is characterized by the formation of necrotizing granulomas in the respiratory tract, necrotizing angiitis, and glomerulonephritis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic inflammatory connective tissue disease marked by skin rashes, joint pain and swelling, inflammation of the kidneys, inflammation of the fibrous tissue surrounding the heart (i.e., the pericardium), as well as other problems.  Not all affected individuals display all of these problems.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune multi-organ disease typically associated with vasculopathy and autoantibody production. Most patients have antinuclear antibodies (ANA). The presence of anti-dsDNA or anti-Smith antibodies are highly-specific.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Chronic inflammatory and autoimmune disease in which the salivary and lacrimal glands undergo progressive destruction by lymphocytes and plasma cells resulting in decreased production of saliva and tears. The primary form, often called sicca syndrome, involves both KERATOCONJUNCTIVITIS SICCA and XEROSTOMIA. The secondary form includes, in addition, the presence of a connective tissue disease, usually rheumatoid arthritis.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune disorder affecting the salivary and lacrimal glands. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of lymphocytic and plasmacytic infiltrates which cause destruction of these glands. It results in dry mouth and dry eyes. It may be associated with the presence of other autoimmune disorders, including rheumatoid arthritis and lupus erythematosus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic systemic disease, primarily of the joints, marked by inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures, widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, and by atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures. Etiology is unknown, but autoimmune mechanisms have been implicated.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation in the synovial membranes and articular surfaces. It manifests primarily as a symmetric, erosive polyarthritis that spares the axial skeleton and is typically associated with the presence in the serum of rheumatoid factor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by skeletal muscle weakness.  It is caused by the blockage of the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Concepts.definition: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by skeletal muscle weakness. It is caused by the blockage of the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autoimmune overlap syndrome characterized by the presence of symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic scleroderma, and polymyositis.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune overlap syndrome characterized by the presence of symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic scleroderma, and polymyositis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic form of cutaneous lupus erythematosus (LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS, CUTANEOUS) in which the skin lesions mimic those of the systemic form but in which systemic signs are rare. It is characterized by the presence of discoid skin plaques showing varying degrees of edema, erythema, scaliness, follicular plugging, and skin atrophy. Lesions are surrounded by an elevated erythematous border. The condition typically involves the face and scalp, but widespread dissemination may occur.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, autoimmune skin condition that manifests with a red, scaling rash, most often found on the face, ears, and scalp; these lesions often lead to permanent scarring and dyspigmentation. Patients may have lesions with or without other symptoms or antibodies suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An endocrine disorder characterized by decreased production of parathyroid hormone by the parathyroid glands. It is usually caused by damage of the parathyroid glands during head and neck surgery. Signs and symptoms include muscle cramps, abdominal pain, dry skin, brittle nails, cataracts, tetany, and convulsions.

Concepts.definition: An endocrine disorder characterized by decreased production of parathyroid hormone by the parathyroid glands. It is usually caused by damage of the parathyroid glands during head and neck surgery. Signs and symptoms include muscle cramps, abdominal pain, dry skin, brittle nails, cataracts, tetany, and convulsions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autoimmune disorder caused by the production of autoantibodies against thyroid tissue. There is progressive destruction of the thyroid follicles leading to hypothyroidism.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune disorder caused by the production of autoantibodies against thyroid tissue. There is progressive destruction of the thyroid follicles leading to hypothyroidism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Hyperthyroidism associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the thyroid gland (goiter), resulting from production of antibodies that are directed against the thyrotropin receptor complex of the follicular epithelial cells.  As a result, the thyroid gland enlarges and secrets increased amounts of thyroid hormones. --2004

Concepts.definition: Hyperthyroidism associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the thyroid gland (goiter), resulting from production of antibodies that are directed against the thyrotropin receptor complex of the follicular epithelial cells. As a result, the thyroid gland enlarges and secretes increased amounts of thyroid hormones.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autoimmune disorder characterized by pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. It is a hypersensitivity reaction resulting in the formation of antibodies against the pulmonary alveoli and the basement membrane of the glomeruli.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune disorder characterized by pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis. It is a hypersensitivity reaction resulting in the formation of antibodies against the pulmonary alveoli and the basement membrane of the glomeruli.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A Brenner tumor of the ovary characterized by papillary structures, nuclear cytologic atypia, and absense of stromal invasion.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm of low malignant potential arising from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of neoplastic atypical urothelial-type cells in a fibrotic stroma without evidence of invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade serous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of serous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  It is often asymptomatic but rarely it may present with abdominal pain or abdominal enlargement due to rupture or torsion.

Concepts.definition: A low grade serous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of serous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  It is often asymptomatic but rarely it may present with abdominal pain or abdominal enlargement due to rupture or torsion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade mucinous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of mucinous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  The mucinous epithelial cells may be of intestinal or endocervical type.

Concepts.definition: A low grade mucinous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of mucinous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  The mucinous epithelial cells may be of intestinal or endocervical type.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade ovarian epithelial tumor composed of an admixture of two or more of the five major cell types: serous, mucinous, endometrioid, clear cell, and Brenner/transitional.  The second or second and third cell types must comprise alone or together at least 10% of the tumor epithelium. The majority of patients present with stage I tumor and a minority present with bilateral disease. Morphologically, it shows papillae with detached cell clusters.  Microinvasion may be seen rarely. (WHO 2003)

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Seromucinous Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Seromucinous Tumor
Concepts.definition: A low grade, non-invasive ovarian epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of atypical neoplastic serous and mucinous cells.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Borderline Ovarian Serous Tumor with Microinvasion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Borderline Ovarian Serous Tumor with Microinvasion
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An ovarian epithelial tumor characterized by the presence of neoplastic serous epithelial cells, atypia, and microinvasion of the ovarian stroma.

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Serous Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Serous Tumor with Microinvasion
Concepts.definition: A low grade ovarian epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic serous epithelial cells, atypia, and microinvasion of the ovarian stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade mucinous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of mucinous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  The mucinous epithelial cells may be of intestinal or endocervical type.

Concepts.definition: A low grade mucinous epithelial neoplasm arising from the ovary.  It is characterized by an atypical proliferation of mucinous-type epithelial cells without evidence of stromal invasion.  The mucinous epithelial cells may be of intestinal or endocervical type.

PermissibleValues.value: Borderline Tumors With Microinvasion \ Mixed Epithelial
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Borderline Tumors With Microinvasion Mixed Epithelial

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Borderline Tumors With Microinvasion Mixed Epithelial
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A low grade ovarian epithelial tumor composed of an admixture of two or more of the five major cell types: serous, mucinous, endometrioid, clear cell, and Brenner/transitional.  The second or second and third cell types must comprise alone or together at least 10% of the tumor epithelium. The majority of patients present with stage I tumor and a minority present with bilateral disease. Morphologically, it shows papillae with detached cell clusters.  Microinvasion may be seen rarely. (WHO 2003)

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Seromucinous Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Seromucinous Tumor
Concepts.definition: A low grade, non-invasive ovarian epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of atypical neoplastic serous and mucinous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm of low malignant potential arising from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of glandular or cystic spaces which contain atypical glandular epithelial cells resembling endometrial cells. The surrounding ovarian stroma is often fibrotic. There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Endometrioid Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Endometrioid Tumor
Concepts.definition: An epithelial neoplasm that arises from the ovary characterized by the presence of glandular or cystic spaces which contain atypical glandular epithelial cells resembling endometrial cells. The surrounding ovarian stroma is often fibrotic. There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

PermissibleValues.value: Borderline Tumors With Microinvasion \ Clear Cell

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An epithelial neoplasm with low malignant potential affecting the ovary.  It is characterized by the presence of clear or hobnail cells.  In some cases, the cells may display nuclear atypia and prominent nucleoli.  When such cells are present, they remain confined to the glands.  There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

Concepts.definition: An epithelial neoplasm with low malignant potential affecting the ovary.  It is characterized by the presence of clear or hobnail cells.  In some cases, the cells may display nuclear atypia and prominent nucleoli.  When such cells are present, they remain confined to the glands.  There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An ovarian epithelial tumor characterized by the presence of neoplastic serous epithelial cells, atypia, and microinvasion of the ovarian stroma.

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Serous Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Serous Tumor with Microinvasion
Concepts.definition: A low grade ovarian epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic serous epithelial cells, atypia, and microinvasion of the ovarian stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm of low malignant potential arising from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of glandular or cystic spaces which contain atypical glandular epithelial cells resembling endometrial cells. The surrounding ovarian stroma is often fibrotic. There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

Concepts.longName: Borderline Ovarian Endometrioid Tumor/Atypical Proliferative Ovarian Endometrioid Tumor
Concepts.definition: An epithelial neoplasm that arises from the ovary characterized by the presence of glandular or cystic spaces which contain atypical glandular epithelial cells resembling endometrial cells. The surrounding ovarian stroma is often fibrotic. There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An epithelial neoplasm with low malignant potential affecting the ovary.  It is characterized by the presence of clear or hobnail cells.  In some cases, the cells may display nuclear atypia and prominent nucleoli.  When such cells are present, they remain confined to the glands.  There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

Concepts.definition: An epithelial neoplasm with low malignant potential affecting the ovary.  It is characterized by the presence of clear or hobnail cells.  In some cases, the cells may display nuclear atypia and prominent nucleoli.  When such cells are present, they remain confined to the glands.  There is no evidence of stromal invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm displaying morphologic, phenotypic, or genotypic characteristics that are clearly not benign but do not permit the establishment of a definitive diagnosis of malignancy.  Such neoplasms may or may not eventually have a more aggressive clinical course.  Representative examples include lymphoproliferations of uncertain malignant potential (e.g., lymphomatoid granulomatosis and lymphomatoid papulosis), borderline ovarian epithelial neoplasms (e.g., borderline ovarian endometrioid tumor and borderline ovarian mucinous tumor), borderline exocrine pancreatic neoplasm (e.g., pancreatic borderline intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm), and primary borderline peritoneal epithelial neoplasm.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm displaying morphologic, phenotypic, or genotypic characteristics that are clearly not benign but do not permit the establishment of a definitive diagnosis of malignancy.  Such neoplasms may or may not eventually have a more aggressive clinical course.  Representative examples include lymphoproliferations of uncertain malignant potential (e.g., lymphomatoid granulomatosis and lymphomatoid papulosis), borderline ovarian epithelial neoplasms (e.g., borderline ovarian endometrioid tumor and borderline ovarian mucinous tumor), borderline exocrine pancreatic neoplasm (e.g., pancreatic borderline intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm), and primary borderline peritoneal epithelial neoplasm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A condition of reduced bone mass, with decreased cortical thickness and a decrease in the number and size of the trabeculae of cancellous bone (but normal chemical composition), resulting in increased fracture incidence. Osteoporosis is classified as primary (Type 1, postmenopausal osteoporosis; Type 2, age-associated osteoporosis; and idiopathic, which can affect juveniles, premenopausal women, and middle-aged men) and secondary osteoporosis (which results from an identifiable cause of bone mass loss).

Concepts.definition: A condition of reduced bone mass, with decreased cortical thickness and a decrease in the number and size of the trabeculae of cancellous bone (but normal chemical composition), resulting in increased fracture incidence. Osteoporosis is classified as primary (Type 1, postmenopausal osteoporosis; Type 2, age-associated osteoporosis; and idiopathic, which can affect juveniles, premenopausal women, and middle-aged men) and secondary osteoporosis (which results from an identifiable cause of bone mass loss).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A metabolic bone disease that results from either a deficiency in vitamin D, or an abnormality in the metabolism of vitamin D, or a deficiency of calcium in the diet.  The most common symptoms are bone pain and muscle weakness.  When it occurs in children it is commonly referred to as rickets. (Diagnostic Surgical Pathology, 3rd ed.) --2003

Concepts.definition: A metabolic bone disease that results from either a deficiency in vitamin D, or an abnormality in the metabolism of vitamin D, or a deficiency of calcium in the diet.  The most common symptoms are bone pain and muscle weakness.  When it occurs in children it is commonly referred to as rickets. (Diagnostic Surgical Pathology, 3rd ed.) --2003

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A noninflammatory degenerative joint disease occurring chiefly in older persons, characterised by degeneration of the articular cartilage, hypertrophy of bone at the margins and changes in the synovial membrane. It is accompanied by pain and stiffness, particularly after prolonged activity.

Concepts.definition: A noninflammatory degenerative joint disease occurring chiefly in older persons, characterised by degeneration of the articular cartilage, hypertrophy of bone at the margins and changes in the synovial membrane. It is accompanied by pain and stiffness, particularly after prolonged activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of disorders that affect the bones secondary to increased levels of minerals or deficient levels of minerals such as calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, and vitamin D.  Representative examples are osteomalacia, osteoporosis, and Paget disease.

Concepts.definition: A group of disorders that affect the bones secondary to increased levels of minerals or deficient levels of minerals such as calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, and vitamin D. Representative examples are osteomalacia, osteoporosis, and Paget disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ischemic necrosis of the bone tissue and the marrow.

Concepts.definition: Ischemic necrosis of the bone tissue and the marrow.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A traumatic injury to the bone in which the continuity of the bone is broken. - 2003

Concepts.definition: A traumatic injury to the bone in which the continuity of the bone is broken.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Subtype; a group forming a type within a larger type.: Craniopharyngiomas (WHO grade I) are benign, partly cystic, epithelial tumors of the sellar region, presumably derived from Rathke pouch epithelium. They affect mainly children and young adults. There are two clinicopathological forms: Adamantinomatous Craniopharyngioma and Papillary Craniopharyngioma. Recent studies indicate that the age distribution and, to some extent, prognosis are different between these two variants. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A group forming a type within a larger type.

A benign, partly cystic, epithelial tumor of the sellar region, presumably derived from Rathke pouch epithelium. It affects mainly children and young adults. There are two clinicopathological forms: adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma and papillary craniopharyngioma. The most significant factor associated with recurrence is the extent of surgical resection, with lesions greater than 5 cm in diameter carrying a markedly worse prognosis. (Adapted from WHO)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Craniopharyngiomas (WHO grade I) are benign, partly cystic, epithelial tumors of the sellar region, presumably derived from Rathke pouch epithelium. They affect mainly children and young adults. There are two clinicopathological forms: Adamantinomatous Craniopharyngioma and Papillary Craniopharyngioma. Recent studies indicate that the age distribution and, to some extent, prognosis are different between these two variants. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A benign, partly cystic, epithelial tumor of the sellar region, presumably derived from Rathke pouch epithelium. It affects mainly children and young adults. There are two clinicopathological forms: adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma and papillary craniopharyngioma. The most significant factor associated with recurrence is the extent of surgical resection, with lesions greater than 5 cm in diameter carrying a markedly worse prognosis. (Adapted from WHO)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare, rapid growing, non-encapsulated benign neoplasm that arises from the cranium. This is an osteolytic lesion. It is characterized by the presence of non-hyperchromatic spindle-shaped fibroblasts, multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells, chronic inflammatory infiltrate, red blood cell extravasation, and high mitotic activity, in a storiform growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: A rare, self-limiting, rapidly growing, non-encapsulated benign osteolytic neoplasm that arises from the cranium. It is characterized by the presence of plump spindle-shaped fibroblasts, multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells, chronic inflammatory infiltrate, red blood cell extravasation, and high mitotic activity.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Adrenal Cortex Neoplasm With Uncertain Malignant Potential

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Adrenal Cortex Neoplasm With Uncertain Malignant Potential
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant (primary or metastatic) neoplasm affecting the adrenal cortex. (NCI05): Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: A neoplasm displaying morphologic, phenotypic, or genotypic characteristics that are clearly not benign but do not permit the establishment of a definitive diagnosis of malignancy.  Such neoplasms may or may not eventually have a more aggressive clinical course.  Representative examples include lymphoproliferations of uncertain malignant potential (e.g., lymphomatoid granulomatosis and lymphomatoid papulosis), borderline ovarian epithelial neoplasms (e.g., borderline ovarian endometrioid tumor and borderline ovarian mucinous tumor), borderline exocrine pancreatic neoplasm (e.g., pancreatic borderline intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm), and primary borderline peritoneal epithelial neoplasm.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant (primary or metastatic) neoplasm affecting the adrenal cortex.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.

A neoplasm displaying morphologic, phenotypic, or genotypic characteristics that are clearly not benign but do not permit the establishment of a definitive diagnosis of malignancy.  Such neoplasms may or may not eventually have a more aggressive clinical course.  Representative examples include lymphoproliferations of uncertain malignant potential (e.g., lymphomatoid granulomatosis and lymphomatoid papulosis), borderline ovarian epithelial neoplasms (e.g., borderline ovarian endometrioid tumor and borderline ovarian mucinous tumor), borderline exocrine pancreatic neoplasm (e.g., pancreatic borderline intraductal papillary-mucinous neoplasm), and primary borderline peritoneal epithelial neoplasm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant (primary or metastatic) neoplasm affecting the adrenal cortex. (NCI05)

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant (primary or metastatic) neoplasm affecting the adrenal cortex.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by the presence of classic and cellular areas.

Concepts.definition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by the presence of classic and cellular areas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A noninflammatory degenerative joint disease occurring chiefly in older persons, characterised by degeneration of the articular cartilage, hypertrophy of bone at the margins and changes in the synovial membrane. It is accompanied by pain and stiffness, particularly after prolonged activity.

Concepts.definition: A noninflammatory degenerative joint disease occurring chiefly in older persons, characterised by degeneration of the articular cartilage, hypertrophy of bone at the margins and changes in the synovial membrane. It is accompanied by pain and stiffness, particularly after prolonged activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathological condition manifested as a pouch or sac opening from a tubular or saccular organ.

Concepts.definition: A pouch formed at a weakened area of wall in a hollow organ structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An aggressive malignant neoplasm of uncertain lineage.  It is characterized by the presence of small round cells in a desmoplastic stroma.  It usually affects children and young adults.  The most common site of involvement is the abdomen.  Patients usually present with abdominal distention, pain, ascites, and a palpable abdominal mass.  The prognosis is usually poor.

Concepts.definition: An aggressive malignant soft tissue neoplasm of uncertain differentiation.  It is characterized by a recurrent chromosomal translocation t(11;22)(p13;q12) and the presence of small round cells in a desmoplastic stroma.  It usually affects children and young adults.  The most common site of involvement is the abdomen.  Patients usually present with abdominal distention, pain, ascites, and a palpable abdominal mass.  The prognosis is usually poor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A reactive, benign fibrous lesion that develops in the periosteum of the femur.  It usually affects boys and there is a history of trauma.  It is characterized by the formation of dense collagen tissue and reactive bone.

Concepts.definition: A reactive, benign fibrous lesion that develops in the periosteum of the femur.  It usually affects boys and there is a history of trauma.  It is characterized by the formation of dense collagen tissue and reactive bone.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mature teratoma characterized by the presence of a cyst which is lined by mature tissue resembling the epidermis and the epidermal appendages. It occurs in the ovary, testis, and extragonadal sites including central nervous system and skin.

Concepts.definition: A mature teratoma characterized by the presence of a cyst which is lined by mature tissue resembling the epidermis and the epidermal appendages. It occurs in the ovary, testis, and extragonadal sites including central nervous system and skin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intermediate cutaneous fibrohistiocytic neoplasm, presenting as a nodular cutaneous mass, most often on the trunk and the proximal extremities.  The tumor diffusely infiltrates the dermis and the subcutaneous tissues.  It is considered a locally aggressive neoplasm, which often recurs but rarely metastasizes.

Concepts.definition: A low grade fibroblastic neoplasm presenting as a nodular cutaneous mass, most often on the trunk and the proximal extremities.  The tumor diffusely infiltrates the dermis and the subcutaneous tissues.  It is considered a locally aggressive neoplasm, which often recurs but rarely metastasizes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solitary, slowly growing nodular mass, most often affecting the extremities.  It is composed of fibrous and histiocytic cells which infiltrate the dermis and occasionally the underlying subcutaneous tissue.  Usually local excision is curative.  Recurrences are reported only in a small minority of cases.

Concepts.definition: A solitary, slowly growing, nodular tumor most often affecting the extremities. It is composed of fibrous and histiocytic cells which infiltrate the dermis and occasionally the underlying subcutaneous tissue.  Usually local excision is curative. Recurrences are reported only in a small minority of cases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: These are rare tumors that affect the hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.  The cells of origin are the histiocytes and accessory cells. (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A group of rare tumors that affect the hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues. The cells of origin are the histiocytes and accessory cells. This category includes the following: Langerhans cell histiocytosis, Langerhans cell sarcoma, indeterminate dendritic cell histiocytosis, interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma, histiocytic sarcoma, disseminated juvenile xanthogranuloma, Erdheim-Chester disease, Rosai-Dorfman-Destombes disease, ALK-positive histiocytosis, and follicular dendritic cell sarcoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A reactive inflammatory disorder affecting the bladder.  It is characterized by the development of small cysts in the bladder wall.  The cysts are lined by metaplastic glandular cells.

Concepts.definition: A reactive inflammatory disorder affecting the bladder.  It is characterized by the development of small cysts in the bladder wall.  The cysts are lined by metaplastic glandular cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A reactive inflammatory disorder affecting the bladder.  It is characterized by the development of small cysts in the bladder wall.  The cysts are lined by urothelial cells.

Concepts.definition: A reactive inflammatory disorder affecting the bladder. It is characterized by the development of small cysts in the bladder wall. The cysts are lined by urothelial cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute infection of the bladder. It is usually caused by bacteria. Signs and symptoms include increased frequency of urination, pain or burning during urination, fever, cloudy or bloody urine, and suprapubic pain.

Concepts.definition: An acute infection of the bladder. It is usually caused by bacteria. Signs and symptoms include increased frequency of urination, pain or burning during urination, fever, cloudy or bloody urine, and suprapubic pain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An epithelial, usually multiloculated neoplasm arising from the bile duct epithelium. It occurs predominantly in females. Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Morphologically, the cystic spaces are lined by columnar epithelium and contain mucinous or serous fluid.

Concepts.definition: An epithelial, usually multiloculated neoplasm arising from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts. It occurs predominantly in females. Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Morphologically, the cystic spaces are lined by columnar epithelium and contain mucinous or serous fluid.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Intrahepatic Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Intrahepatic Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Concepts.longName: Intrahepatic Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm
Concepts.definition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic bile ducts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An idiopathic disorder characterized by the degeneration of the aortic media tissue and formation of cyst-like spaces.  It may lead to aortic dissection.

Concepts.definition: An idiopathic disorder characterized by the degeneration of the aortic media tissue and formation of cyst-like spaces. It may lead to aortic dissection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A serous neoplasm in which the cysts and papillae are lined by a single layer of cells without atypia, architectural complexity or invasion.

Concepts.definition: A serous neoplasm in which the cysts and papillae are lined by a single layer of cells without atypia, architectural complexity or invasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or low malignant potential cystic epithelial neoplasm composed of cells which contain intracytoplasmic mucin. It may arise from the ovary, pancreas, appendix, and lung.

Concepts.definition: A benign or low malignant potential cystic epithelial neoplasm composed of cells which contain intracytoplasmic mucin. It may arise from the ovary, pancreas, appendix, and lung.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Any Benign Hyperplasia Metaplastic Subtype Cystadenoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Any Benign Hyperplasia Metaplastic Subtype Cystadenoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One, some, every, or all without specification.: (beh-NINE) Not cancerous; does not invade nearby tissue or spread to other parts of the body.: An abnormal increase in the number of cells in an organ or a tissue with consequent enlargement.: Pertaining to or characterized by metaplasia.: Subtype; a group forming a type within a larger type.: A benign or borderline cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The epithelial cells line the cystic spaces which contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenomas.

Concepts.definition: One, some, every, or all without specification.

For neoplasms, a non-infiltrating and non-metastasizing neoplastic process that is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (e.g., severe atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, tumor cell necrosis, and abnormal mitoses). For other conditions, a process that is mild in nature and not dangerous to health.
An abnormal increase in the number of cells in an organ or a tissue with consequent enlargement.
Pertaining to or characterized by metaplasia.
A group forming a type within a larger type.

A benign or borderline cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The epithelial cells line the cystic spaces which contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or borderline neoplasm that arises from the ovaries and the fallopian tubes. It is characterized by the presence of cystic glandular structures and fibrous tissue.

Concepts.definition: A benign or borderline neoplasm that arises from the ovaries and the fallopian tubes. It is characterized by the presence of cystic glandular structures and fibrous tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive adenocarcinoma characterized by cystic changes and the presence of malignant glandular cells which contain intracytoplasmic mucin. It may arise from the ovary, pancreas, appendix, and lung.

Concepts.definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma characterized by cystic changes and the presence of malignant glandular cells which contain intracytoplasmic mucin. It may arise from the ovary, pancreas, appendix, and lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.

Concepts.longName: Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm with an Associated Invasive Carcinoma
Concepts.definition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (ma-LIG-nant) Cancerous; a growth with a tendency to invade and destroy nearby tissue and spread to other parts of the body.: Subtype; a group forming a type within a larger type.: A malignant cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The malignant epithelial cells invade the stroma.  The cystic spaces contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenocarcinomas.

Concepts.definition: Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.
A group forming a type within a larger type.

A malignant cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The malignant epithelial cells invade the stroma.  The cystic spaces contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenocarcinomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cystic adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of relatively uniform neoplastic cells which produce pancreatic enzymes and are arranged in acinar patterns. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, weight loss, nausea, and diarrhea. It usually has an aggressive clinical course.

Concepts.definition: A cystic adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of relatively uniform neoplastic cells which produce pancreatic enzymes and are arranged in acinar patterns. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, weight loss, nausea, and diarrhea. It usually has an aggressive clinical course.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The malignant epithelial cells invade the stroma.  The cystic spaces contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenocarcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A malignant cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the glandular epithelium.  The malignant epithelial cells invade the stroma.  The cystic spaces contain serous or mucinous fluid.  Representative examples include ovarian and pancreatic cystadenocarcinomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A single, fluid-filled cyst in the breast parenchyma.

Concepts.definition: A single, fluid-filled cyst in the breast parenchyma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare congenital malformation in the larynx.  It is characterized by the presence of an air-filled sac within the laryngeal wall which may bulge on the neck.

Concepts.definition: A rare congenital malformation in the larynx. It is characterized by the presence of an air-filled sac within the laryngeal wall which may bulge on the neck.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cyst lined by tissue that resembles synovial villi.

Concepts.definition: A cyst lined by tissue that resembles synovial villi.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cystic lesion that arises from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of cystic spaces that contain fluid and a solid tissue component.

Concepts.definition: A cystic lesion that arises from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of cystic spaces that contain fluid and a solid tissue component.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cystic dilatation that occurs in any part of the biliary tree.

Concepts.definition: A cystic dilatation that occurs in any part of the biliary tree.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Solitary lesions of bone that typically cause a bulging of the overlying cortex bearing some resemblance to the saccular protrusion of the aortic wall in aortic aneurysm, hence the name. (Dorland, 27th ed)

Concepts.definition: A locally aggressive and destructive benign cystic neoplasm of the bone. It is characterized by the formation of multiloculated hemorrhagic cystic spaces which are separated by fibrous septa. It can arise from any bone, but usually affects the metaphysis of long bones.  It manifests with pain and swelling and may recur following curettage.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (sist) A sac or capsule filled with fluid.

Concepts.definition: A sac-like closed membranous structure that may be empty or contain fluid or amorphous material.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A craniopharyngioma composed of sheets of squamous epithelium which separate to form pseudopapillae. This variant typically lacks nuclear palisading, wet keratin, calcification, and cholesterol deposits. Clinically, endocrine deficiencies are more often associated with papillary craniopharyngioma than with the adamantinomatous type. (Adapted from WHO.)

Concepts.definition: A craniopharyngioma composed of sheets of squamous epithelium which separate to form pseudopapillae. This variant typically lacks nuclear palisading, wet keratin, calcification, and cholesterol deposits. Clinically, endocrine deficiencies are more often associated with papillary craniopharyngioma than with the adamantinomatous type. (Adapted from WHO)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infectious fungal disease that occurs most often in the skin, ears, nasal sinuses, and lungs of people with suppressed immune systems.

Concepts.definition: An infection that is caused by Aspergillus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the hair follicle.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the hair follicle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intermediate cutaneous fibrohistiocytic neoplasm, characterized by pleomorphic spindle cells, usually affecting the actinic-damaged skin of the elderly.  The tumor presents as a single cutaneous nodule which is often ulcerated.  Microscopically, it is indistinguishable from pleomorphic forms of malignant fibrous histiocytoma, and it is regarded by many experts as a superficial form of the latter.  The vast majority of patients have an excellent prognosis following conservative therapy.  Recurrences are infrequent, and metastasis is rare. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: An intermediate cutaneous mesenchymal neoplasm of uncertain differentiation, usually affecting the actinic-damaged skin of the elderly.  The tumor presents as a single cutaneous nodule which is often ulcerated.  Microscopically, it is characterized by the presence of highly atypical cytologic features, pleomorphism and abundant mitotic figures. The vast majority of patients have an excellent prognosis following conservative therapy. Recurrences are infrequent, and metastasis is rare.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A small, slow growing, benign neoplasm arising from the tendon sheaths. The tumor is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts and collagenous stroma formation.

Concepts.definition: A small, slow growing, benign neoplasm arising from the tendon sheaths. The tumor is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts and collagenous stroma formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A localized neoplasm of probable fibroblastic derivation. It is characterized by the presence of round to spindle-shaped cells, hylanized stroma formation, thin-walled branching blood vessels, and thin bands of collagen.

Concepts.definition: A localized neoplasm of probable fibroblastic derivation. It is characterized by the presence of round to spindle-shaped cells, hylanized stroma formation, thin-walled branching blood vessels, and thin bands of collagen.

PermissibleValues.value: Fibrous Tumors \ Reactive Myofibroblastic Proliferation At Visceral Locations

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multinodular intermediate fibrocytic neoplasm that arises from soft tissue or viscera, in children and young adults.  It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped myofibroblasts, and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate composed of eosinophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells.

Concepts.definition: A multinodular intermediate fibroblastic neoplasm that arises from soft tissue or viscera, in children and young adults.  It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts and myofibroblasts, and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate composed of eosinophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rapid growing, poorly circumscribed, non-encapsulated, benign neoplasm that arises from the subcutaneous tissues. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, round ganglion-like cells, myxoid to collagenous stroma formation, and high mitotic activity.

Concepts.definition: A rapidly growing, poorly circumscribed, mass-forming proliferation that arises from the subcutaneous tissues. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, round ganglion-like cells, myxoid to collagenous stroma formation, and high mitotic activity. It recurs only rarely following local excision and does not metastasize.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rapid growing, non-encapsulated benign neoplasm that arises from the soft tissues. It is characterized by the presence of non-hyperchromatic spindle-shaped fibroblasts, multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells, chronic inflammatory infiltrate, red blood cell extravasation, and high mitotic activity, in a storiform growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: A self-limiting, rapidly growing, non-encapsulated benign neoplasm that arises from the soft tissues. It is characterized by the presence of plump spindle-shaped fibroblasts, multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells, chronic inflammatory infiltrate, red blood cell extravasation, and high mitotic activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by non-neoplastic bone formation in soft tissues. It usually follows blunt trauma and bleeding in the deep soft tissues.

Concepts.definition: A self-limited benign neoplasm characterized by a zonal architecture. It is composed of spindle cells oriented randomly or in short intersecting fascicles. Peripherally, the spindle cells merge with osteoblasts that rim and populate ill-defined trabeculae and sheets of unmineralized woven bone, which is surrounded by well-formed trabecular and cortical-type bone that remodels into lamellar bone. Treatment is usually simple excision. Prognosis is excellent; recurrence is uncommon. (WHO 2020)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign neoplasm arising from the soft tissues. It is characterized by the presence of myofibroblastic hyperchromatic spindle cells, hylanized stroma formation, calcification, necrosis, and a multinodular growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: A benign, multifocal, nodular and well-circumscribed neoplasm usually seen as a congenital neoplasm or in the first year of life. It is characterized by a biphasic growth pattern and is composed of small, undifferentiated mesenchymal cells associated with branching thin-walled vessels and more mature neoplastic spindle cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm in a collagenous stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign localized neoplasm arising from the subcutaneous tissues and skeletal muscle. It is characterized by the presence of myofibroblastic hyperchromatic spindle cells, hylanized stroma formation, calcification, necrosis, and a multinodular growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: A benign, localized, nodular and well-circumscribed neoplasm usually seen as a congenital neoplasm or in the first year of life. It is characterized by a biphasic growth pattern and is composed of small, undifferentiated mesenchymal cells associated with branching thin-walled vessels and more mature neoplastic spindle cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm in a collagenous stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fibrous Tumors \ Ischemic
Fibro-Osseous Lesions

A benign, slow-growing tumor arising from the soft tissues usually in the mid-thoracic region of the elderly. It is characterized by the presence of paucicellular collagenous tissue, adipocytes and a predominance of large coarse elastic fibers arranged in globules.

Concepts.definition: A benign, slow-growing tumor arising from the soft tissues usually in the mid-thoracic region of the elderly. It is characterized by the presence of paucicellular collagenous tissue, adipocytes and a predominance of large coarse elastic fibers arranged in globules.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solitary, slowly growing nodular mass, most often affecting the extremities.  It is composed of fibrous and histiocytic cells which infiltrate the dermis and occasionally the underlying subcutaneous tissue.  Usually local excision is curative.  Recurrences are reported only in a small minority of cases.

Concepts.definition: A solitary, slowly growing, nodular tumor most often affecting the extremities. It is composed of fibrous and histiocytic cells which infiltrate the dermis and occasionally the underlying subcutaneous tissue.  Usually local excision is curative. Recurrences are reported only in a small minority of cases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of ovarian thecoma characterized by the presence of lutein cells. It is associated with a lower frequency of estrogenic manifestations compared to typical thymomas. In a minority of cases androgenic manifestations are present. It may also be associated with sclerosing peritonitis which presents with ascites and symptoms of bowel obstruction.

Concepts.definition: A variant of ovarian thecoma characterized by the presence of lutein cells. It is associated with a lower frequency of estrogenic manifestations compared to typical thecomas. In a minority of cases androgenic manifestations are present.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sex cord-stromal tumor that arises from the ovary or the testis. Representative examples include fibroma, fibrosarcoma, and thecoma.

Concepts.definition: A sex cord-stromal tumor that arises from the ovary or the testis. Representative examples include fibroma, fibrosarcoma, and thecoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fibromatosis arising from the soft tissues of the penis. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, and an infiltrative growth pattern.  It causes the penis to bend when it becomes erect.

Concepts.definition: Fibromatosis arising from the soft tissues of the penis. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, and an infiltrative growth pattern.  It causes the penis to bend when it becomes erect.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic disorder of unknown etiology charaterized by pain, stiffness, and tenderness in the muscles of the neck, shoulders, back, hips, arms, and legs  Other signs and symptoms include headaches, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and painful menstruation.

Concepts.definition: A chronic disorder of unknown etiology characterized by pain, stiffness, and tenderness in the muscles of neck, shoulders, back, hips, arms, and legs. Other signs and symptoms include headaches, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and painful menstruation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A superficial fibromatosis arising from soft tissue of the plantar regions. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, hypercellularity, and an infiltrative growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: A superficial fibromatosis arising from soft tissue of the plantar regions. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, hypercellularity, and an infiltrative growth pattern.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A superficial fibromatosis arising from the soft tissue of the palm. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, and an infiltrative growth pattern. It predominantly affects adult males.

Concepts.definition: A superficial fibromatosis arising from the soft tissue of the palm. It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, and an infiltrative growth pattern. It predominantly affects adult males.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic systemic disease, primarily of the joints, marked by inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures, widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, and by atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures. Etiology is unknown, but autoimmune mechanisms have been implicated.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation in the synovial membranes and articular surfaces. It manifests primarily as a symmetric, erosive polyarthritis that spares the axial skeleton and is typically associated with the presence in the serum of rheumatoid factor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fatty replacement and damage to the hepatocytes not related to alcohol use. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Concepts.definition: Fatty replacement and damage to the hepatocytes not related to alcohol use. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A WHO grade II meningioma with increased mitotic activity or three or more of the following features: increased cellularity, small cells with high nuclear to cytoplasm ratio, prominent nucleoli, uninterrupted patternless or sheet-like growth, and foci of spontaneous or geographic necrosis. (Adapted from WHO 2000.)

Concepts.definition: A WHO grade II meningioma characterized by the presence of brain invasion and an increased mitotic activity, or at least three of the following morphologic features: small cells, high cellularity, prominent nucleoli, lack of architectural pattern, and necrosis.

PermissibleValues.value: Neuroendocrine Tumor (Includes Carcinoid) \ Multiple Endocrine Neoplasm (MEN) Type 2A

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by mutation of the RET gene. Patients develop medullary thyroid carcinomas, and may also develop pheochromocytomas and parathyroid gland hyperplasia.

Concepts.definition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by mutation of the RET gene. Patients develop medullary thyroid carcinomas, and may also develop pheochromocytomas and parathyroid gland hyperplasia.

PermissibleValues.value: Neuroendocrine Tumor (Includes Carcinoid) \ Multiple Endocrine Neoplasm (MEN) Type 2B

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by mutation of the RET gene. Patients develop medullary thyroid carcinomas and numerous neural defects including neuromas.

Concepts.definition: Multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by mutation of the RET gene. Patients develop medullary thyroid carcinomas and numerous neural defects including neuromas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by the presence of interlacing fascicles of fibroblastic cells, low mitotic activity, and collagen formation.

Concepts.definition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by the presence of interlacing fascicles of fibroblastic cells, low mitotic activity, and collagen formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by increased cellularity, sheet-like proliferation of fibroblastic cells, and increased mitotic activity.  Necrotic changes are commonly present.

Concepts.definition: A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by increased cellularity, sheet-like proliferation of fibroblastic cells, and increased mitotic activity.  Necrotic changes are commonly present.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any abnormality, anatomical or biochemical, evident at birth or during the neonatal period.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormality, anatomical or biochemical, evident at birth or during the neonatal period.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Condyloma acuminatum that is associated with the presence of dysplastic epithelial changes.

Concepts.definition: Condyloma acuminatum that is associated with the presence of dysplastic epithelial changes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sexually transmitted papillary growth caused by the human papilloma virus. It usually arises in the skin and mucous membranes of the perianal region and external genitalia.

Concepts.definition: A sexually transmitted papillary growth caused by the human papillomavirus. It usually arises in the skin and mucous membranes of the perianal region and external genitalia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign breast lesion characterized by the presence of fibrosis with stellate appearance in the parenchyma. The lesions are often multiple and bilateral. Grossly, the lesions are irregular and firm and resemble carcinoma. Microscopically, the stellate lesions are composed of dense, hyalinized collagen. Entrapped in the collagen are tubules. There is no evidence of cytologic atypia.

Concepts.definition: A benign breast lesion characterized by the presence of fibrosis with stellate appearance in the parenchyma.  The lesions are often multiple and bilateral.  Grossly, the lesions are irregular and firm and resemble carcinoma.  Microscopically, the stellate lesions are composed of dense, hyalinized collagen.  Entrapped in the collagen are tubules.  There is no evidence of cytologic atypia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare tumor containing unequivocal elements of both hepatocellular and cholangiocarcinoma that are intimately admixed.  This tumor should be distinguished from separate hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma arising in the same liver.  The prognosis of this tumor is poor.

Concepts.definition: A rare tumor containing unequivocal elements of both hepatocellular and cholangiocarcinoma that are intimately admixed.  This tumor should be distinguished from separate hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma arising in the same liver.  The prognosis of this tumor is poor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-cancerous thyroid gland nodule that contains colloid material.

Concepts.definition: A non-cancerous thyroid gland nodule that contains colloid material.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign neoplasm characterized by the presence of glandular structures which contain clear cells and a fibrotic stroma.

Concepts.definition: A benign or borderline neoplasm characterized by the presence of glandular structures which contain clear cells and a fibrotic stroma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An insidious poorly circumscribed neoplasm arising from the deep soft tissues. It is characterized by the presence of elongated spindle-shaped fibroblasts, collagenous stroma formation, and an infiltrative growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: An insidious, locally aggressive, poorly circumscribed neoplasm arising from the deep soft tissues. It is characterized by the presence of elongated spindle-shaped fibroblasts, collagenous stroma formation, and an infiltrative growth pattern. It lacks metastatic potential.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A congenital disorder of the intrahepatic bile ducts characterized by abnormal embryonal development of the ductal plates.

Concepts.definition: A congenital disorder of the intrahepatic bile ducts characterized by abnormal embryonal development of the ductal plates.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathological condition manifested as a pouch or sac opening from a tubular or saccular organ.

Concepts.definition: A pouch formed at a weakened area of wall in a hollow organ structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A condition marked by small sacs or pouches (diverticula) in the walls of an organ such as the stomach or colon. These sacs can become inflamed and cause a condition called diverticulitis, which may be a risk factor for certain types of cancer.

Concepts.definition: A finding indicating the presence of multiple pouches, usually in the colonic or gastric wall.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infection that develops in the diverticula of the intestinal tract. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis.

Concepts.definition: An infection that develops in the diverticula of the intestinal tract. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 10.16.20 Updated definition with current NCIt. mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by chronic inflammation involving all layers of the intestinal wall, noncaseating granulomas affecting the intestinal wall and regional lymph nodes, and transmural fibrosis. Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum; the colon is the second most common site of involvement. --2004

Concepts.definition: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by chronic inflammation involving all layers of the intestinal wall, noncaseating granulomas affecting the intestinal wall and regional lymph nodes, and transmural fibrosis. Crohn disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum; the colon is the second most common site of involvement.

PermissibleValues.value: Gastrointestinal/Liver Disorders \ Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Not Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Not Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Not Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Not Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease

PermissibleValues.value: Gastrointestinal/Liver Disorders \ Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Congenital Hepatic Fibrosis Associated With Polycystic Kidney Disease

A type of microscopic colitis of unknown etiology. It is characterized by the presence of collagen deposits in the lamina propria of the colonic mucosa. Patients present with chronic watery diarrhea. Colonoscopy reveals normal-appearing mucosa. The diagnosis is made with the microscopic examination of the colonic biopsy samples.

Concepts.definition: A type of microscopic colitis of unknown etiology. It is characterized by the presence of collagen deposits in the lamina propria of the colonic mucosa. Patients present with chronic watery diarrhea. Colonoscopy reveals normal-appearing mucosa. The diagnosis is made with the microscopic examination of the colonic biopsy samples.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autoimmune inflammatory disorder characterized by destruction of the small intrahepatic bile ducts. It affects predominantly females and it may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure. Patients have antimitochondrial and antinuclear antibodies in the peripheral blood.

Concepts.definition: An autoimmune inflammatory disorder characterized by destruction of the small intrahepatic bile ducts. It affects predominantly females and it may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure. Patients have antimitochondrial and antinuclear antibodies in the peripheral blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Liver cirrhosis in alcoholics.

Concepts.definition: A disorder of the liver characterized by the presence of fibrotic scar tissue instead of healthy liver tissue. This condition is attributed to excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by replacement of the liver parenchyma with fibrous tissue and regenerative nodules. It is usually caused by alcoholisms, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Complications include the development of ascites, esophageal varices, bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by replacement of the liver parenchyma with fibrous tissue and regenerative nodules. It is usually caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Complications include the development of ascites, esophageal varices, bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.
